cluster_relations.rel_desc: The formation of black holes is one of the key aspects discussed about black holes.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DescriptiveScope: listed as one of several key aspects

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The formation of black holes is presented as one aspect of black holes being discussed.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Scope: dimension in which black holes are studied

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The properties of black holes are treated as a key aspect of black holes.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Scope: physical and conceptual attributes considered

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject topic includes the object as one of its aspects, dimensions, or subtopics of discussion.
args.justification: In this instance, 'black holes' (subject) is the broader topic and 'formation of black holes' (object) is one specific aspect of that topic, so the predicate should run from whole-topic to aspect.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is an aspect, dimension, or subtopic of the broader topic given by the object.
args.justification: In both cases, the subject ('formation of black holes'; 'properties of black holes') is described as an aspect of the broader topic 'black holes', so the predicate should run from aspect to whole-topic.
All three relations connect a broader topic with a conceptual aspect or dimension of that topic within the same subject area (black holes), so they belong to the same class of topic–aspect relations.
An aspect is a conceptual part or component of a broader topic, so these relations fall under a general part–whole grouping rather than, for example, causality or temporality.

All three relations connect a broader topic with a conceptual aspect or dimension of that topic within the same subject area (black holes), so they belong to the same class of topic–aspect relations.
